Diesel Music biography:
"In 1991 Lisa signed a record deal with Diesel Music and under the guidance of TorbjÃƒÆ’Ã‚Â¶rn Sten she began a successful collaboration with songwriter Mauro Scocco and producer Johan Ekelund. She started recording in Swedish instead of English and developed her singing technique and interpretation through Scocco's lyrics and Ekelund's production ideas. Her expression matured and Lisa began to evolve as a singer with storytelling qualities who possessed an ability to touch and move people with her impressive voice. 
The first album to emerge from this collaboration was 'Himlen Runt HÃƒÆ’Ã‚Â¶rnet' ('Heaven Around the Corner') which was released in 1992 and became Lisa's big breakthrough with sales of more than 500 000 copies across Scandinavia. It was recorded and mixed at ABBA's legendary Polar Music Studios by Ekelund and one of Benny Andersson's longtime collaborators, technician Bernard LÃƒÆ’Ã‚Â¶hr. Several of Sweden's foremost pop/soul musicians played an important role in the sound and arrangement. A special mention should be given to guitarist Mattias Torell, saxophonist David Wilschewski and former ABBA drummer Per Lindvall. The album was awarded a recordbreaking five Swedish Grammies in the categories Female Singer Of The Year, Album Of The Year, Song Of The Year, Composer Of The Year (Mauro Scocco) and Producer Of The Year (Johan Ekelund), three of daily newspaper Aftonbladet's annual RockbjÃƒÆ’Ã‚Â¶rnen Awards in the categories Female Singer Of The Year, Album Of The Year and Song Of The Year, two Danish Grammies in the categories International Singer Of The Year and International Album Of The Year, as well as gold and platinum records in several Nordic countries. An extensive tour followed which established Lisa as one of Scandinavia's most popular artists. 
Together with Scocco and Ekelund she created an almost trendsetting sound of soul in Swedish that would come to leave an imprint in the minds of many up and coming singers. 
'Himlen Runt HÃƒÆ’Ã‚Â¶rnet' was also released in an English version, 'Ticket to Heaven', in parts of Europe and Japan, but Lisa never felt that the collaboration with the international record company BMG Ariola (today Sony-BMG) gave her enough respect, understanding or stimulation. She wasn't willing to continue working towards an international career based solely on commercialism."
